The first question I would ask: what does being "objective" really mean?
Say- if we were to ask the AI to grade a whole student body, a school for example- on a piece of creative writing- how would the grades received by the students from the AI, correlate with the grades between different teachers. What would that tell us about the AI and the teachers? 
How would we make an optimal "marking" machine, while improving ourselves by using it?
How do we even begin to decide what a "statistical anomaly is", when the question is no longer- concensus, but optimization. 

The obvious answer is trial and error, but the thing you are playing with here- education, is not unimportant. In fact, if the "error" part goes really wrong, that's a recipe for apocalypse. Terrible education and unsustainable beliefs are the most likely thing that might end our existence. That's my opinion though. I just don't want to see us fail.

This is really impressive and could absolutely be a game changer for education.  Unfortunately he's quite wrong when it comes to the last couple minutes of this talk.  We can't wait for "when the problems arise" because, for AI, that is too late.  None of the past is relevant to this new situation, because we've never had to deal with what is effectively alien entities with intelligence on par to or greater than our own.  That makes this completely different than anything humans have faced before.  If we let AIs get smarter than humans without dealing with all the safety aspects BEFORE THEN it will be too late.  This is a situation where humanity can't wait until there are problems to try and fix them after the fact.  I'd like to point out that all the positive thinking in the world regarding education won't matter - if there aren't humans to educate in the future.  On our current path with attitudes like this (towards AI safety) where we race ahead building AIs that are well beyond what we can ensure safety for will lead to a horrible outcome for humanity.  It doesn't need to be that way, but doing it safely would require patience and a focus on safety instead of rapid unchecked progress but too many people just don't take AI safety seriously and if this trend continues it has a high likelihood of leading to disaster.

Khan's example about analyzing the Great Gatsby is one of the dumbest, most dangerous things I've ever seen an educator suggest. Is that something a real-life reading tutor would do in a million years? Pretend to be the main character of the book so that they can pedantically explain the book's symbolism? What reading skill, what critical thinking skill, is that conversation supposed to be encouraging? Are we supposed to be teaching students that the protagonist of a novel is the best authority on the symbolism of that novel? Khan is patting this student on the back for reading Spark Notes in a slightly more tech savvy, nerdy way. How can people watch this man and think he has any clue what's good for students in an English Literature class? 

This is lunacy!! We've drank the Silicon Valley kool-aid, and there's only one direction this is going... the absolute collapse of critical thinking, which will lead to endemic depression and addiction among adults. The trend is already here. I promise you, students today are NOT going to look back on this time and think "Wow, I'm so glad that an AI did 50% of my school work for me, I'm so much better off for it!" You might argue that schools will raise standards to adjust for the abilities of AI. If you believe that, you must not work in a public school. Districts are fighting tooth and nail just to show basic proficiency on end-of-year exams. We're in a race to the bottom, and AI is anything but a golden bullet.

I love the idea behind this and from what he has shown it looks great. One aspect I wonder about relates to the closing remarks "if AI can be used to enhance HI (human intelligence, human potential and human purpose)". 

I wonder if the advancements in these technologies actually present a significant challenge for human purpose. I think there is value in learning for its own sake. But there is something about knowing that what you are learning can be done effortlessly and better (assuming it is an effective tutor) by the bot teaching you that challenges the practical utility of the learning.

I don't mean to be a downer here. I think we have to move forward, there is no putting this back in the box. But it does present challenges even for very positive use cases.

Augmenting Human Intelligence (HI as you say it) with the help of AI seems to a "noble" direction. However, you have to give space for a long thought to a simple question: Does this democratization of AI-tutors could possibly get rid of the "human connection" in one of the very basic aspects of our life, i.e., education. I hope in such an influenctial and potential position Mr. Sal khan could comment on his thoughts about this. 

On the other hand, he has not mentioned a single aspect about the data that this AI has trained on and would train on in the future. What kind of biases or errors are hidden in this data? Who screens this data? 
This probably is going to be the most impactful AI tool ever and it is going to touch every learning child and adult in the corners of the world. So, these and more questions need to be listened to and debated in length especially by the creators of these tools. Otherwise they are just being irresponsible and/or getting distracted in awe of what their creation can achieve. And there are one-too-many examples in history of the consequences of such a direction.

The speaker in this text argues that AI can transform education by providing every student on the planet with an artificially intelligent personal tutor and every teacher with an amazing, artificially intelligent teaching assistant. This, he says, can mitigate the fears that students will use AI to cheat, thereby not learning, and completely undermine education as we know it. The speaker demonstrates the early stages of their AI, Khanmigo, which is being used to tutor students in math, computer programming, and other subjects. Khanmigo can detect student mistakes, ask students to explain their reasoning, and help them to better understand concepts. It can also quiz students, answer their questions, and connect the video content they are watching with other ideas. The speaker says that using AI to provide every student with an amazing personal tutor could be the biggest positive transformation that education has ever seen.

No recognition at all of the importance of human connection in education, especially pre-college.  When a student feels cared about, cheered on, recognized as a person of value by a teacher, the result can be and often is transformative.  Even if AI could be taught to mimic that, the student would know there‚Äôs no person there.  If they were fooled into thinking of AI as a person, that would be psychologically fraudulent and might have very negative consequences down the road.
Why is this not a voice interaction between the AI and the student?

A great talk and exciting to see how Khan Academy is approaching this thoughtfully and with optimism. I adore that Khanmigo is being taught to "think" before it "speaks." A novel concept. Still many questions. Top of my list: At what age does the Khan Academy team think kids should be exposed to AI? How will the data from student's conversations with Khanmigo be presented to teachers in a way that's useful? Will using Khanmigo for lesson planning lead to better or more uniform pedagogy? How do we prepare students to discern and differentiate between speaking with an AI powered historical figure vs. fictional character vs. inanimate object (the Mississippi River?). The two sigma data is interesting and relevant. How much thought is being put into where these tools dovetail with children's cognitive development and differences, including supporting executive function development. Based on Sal's comments at the end of the talk, he clearly believes human interaction matters... but I'm curious about his specific thoughts on the where/why/when/how?

Sal is awesome but it is sad seeing that after all those years, he still doesn't get it. The paradigm of coercive schooling is fundamentally broken and no amount of tinkering, AI-powered or otherwise, is going to fix it. We need to abolish the 'coercion' in schooling, i.e. the paradigm that we can and should force students to learn and force them to learn what we think students should or need to learn.

I don't know if this is going to be a Super Tutor.  Here is the problem: all this is doing is giving on demand replies based on information that is already out there.  There is certainly efficacy in that.  However, education is fundamentally a human experience.  It's about people, peers, elevating one another into discourse communities.  So while we can "learn" more quickly because the information is now more on demand than it was before, it does nothing to really elevate human beings.  Only human beings can do that.  So while I think this will be helpful, it is not going to shift the curve like that shown at the beginning of the talk. In the end, unless teachers and students bring the necessary energy and eagerness to the experience (which AI cannot and never will be able to provide) AI will remain souped up search engine and nothing more.

Still you cannot understand how scary it is‚Ä¶ ü§î

I lost all the thousand ton of respect that I had for Sal Khan after listening to this talk. First, he's going to "give" "everyone" in the "world" -- you got the point -- he's THAT filled with a strange brown man's burden filled by Sillicon Valley. Khan Academy has been a blessing for those who have had access to it. But look at the attempts to give laptops to kids around the world. Look at the increasing digital divide. And Khan should know about the world beyond California. He may be right about AI's ability to do the math and even do a thousand things with language. But he's looking at the world through his company's lens alone: he's lost perspective (or perspectives). The "super tutor" is fine -- but wouldn't it need to first become capable of "factually correct" answers on simple issues, not to mention leaving it alone to guide children?! He seems to believe AI is going to tackle complexities of history and philosophy, and he also seems to believe it can help students with current events. All that while, he completely ignores that these tools are only good with the most motivated students.  AI tools are extremely helpful in some cases, hit or miss, but they are also based on the fundamental flaw: they're agnostic to facts, contexts, cultures, and ethics BY DESIGN, unless certain behaviors are subtracted from them, and that doesn't go very far. I wouldn't be so bothered by this presentation if it wasn't done like a promo, instead of an educator making a critical and nuanced assessment -- and we know why: Khan has money to make from this marketing. I've lost my trust of him entirely because of this.
I have to add that I fully admire the last segment in which Khan shares the caution and the need for the positive actors to play active roles.
This was predicted in The Diamond Age by Neal Stephenson decades ago. Crazy to see the first version of it is finally here

Augmenting Human Intelligence (HI as you say it) with the help of AI seems to be a "noble" direction. However, you have to give space for a long thought to a simple question: Does this democratization of AI-tutors could possibly get rid of the "human connection" in one of the very basic aspects of our life, i.e., education. I hope in such an influenctial and potential position Mr. Sal khan could comment on his thoughts about this. 

On the other hand, he has not mentioned a single aspect about the data that this AI has trained on and would train on in the future. What kind of biases or errors are hidden in this data? Who screens this data? 
This probably is going to be the most impactful AI tool ever and it is going to touch every learning child and adult in the corners of the world. So, these and more questions need to be listened to and debated in length especially by the creators of these tools. Otherwise they are just being irresponsible and/or getting distracted in awe of what their creation can achieve. And there are one-too-many examples in history of the consequences of such a direction.

An AI assistant lesson planner wouldn't save me ANY time. What would really, REALLY save me time is something that would grade long-form test answers, which takes me over 6 hours in a normal week, and actually giving feedback for each response is so daunting a task that I admit I just don't give any feedback. What would really help me and many teachers would be a TEACHING ASSISTANT THAT GRADES AND GIVES FEEDBACK. It would also be great if it could let teachers know any trends in student response errors that could indicate a standard is not being mastered by students. Thank You!

As a parent, and an educator, I would like for an AI tool that: knows every question my learner has *ever* been asked, and every answer they ever gave (and for it to derive from that all it can about the best possible ways in which to deliver any kind of information to them to maximize comprehension of any concept); I'd like for it to be able to articulate to educators and other AI tools what it knows about the learner WRT to the subject at hand and exactly the way in which the subject should be delivered &/OR for it to serve as an interface to others, consuming what they intend to deliver and being the educator, delivering concepts in exactly the way necessary to maximize comprehension. It should be their lifelong, personalized tutor. Beyond adapting to them, it should also work with them to improve their capacity and ability to comprehend new concepts; utilizing its extensive knowledge of them it should identify potential gaps & weaknesses and develop programs to make improvements in those areas, to expand & enhance their capacity and potential. Finally, it should keep abreast of developments in the understanding of how to deliver concepts effectively through the proven strategies of the millions (billions?) of other AI educators, capitalizing on their successes to further its own ability to educate.

AI certainly has intereting applications in education in contrary to what panicked educators think. However does it create two more problems for every one it solves? The gain could be achieved by simply providing better training for teachers and teaching assistants,  challenging though it might be. Human teachers when well trained can support and encourage their students in ways AI at the current level can not. But what we find is that students will by default go to a chatbot to ask questions or help on their homework even if their teachers are good (due to social or psychological factors) and become increasingly dependant on owners of these AI platforms whose policy may or may not always be in the students' best interest.

Yeah, AI will be a great tool in  education moving forward, but the part that i think gets overlooked is if you want to still do the thing you were doing before.

Like interacting with AI is a lot of fun, using it to co-write stories is a blast... have it teach me in a way no teacher or even the biggest group of teachers possibly can is all great, but the teal question is will the students still want to learn? 

And the thing about mastery is, it is quite falsely human defined. 
Like imagine struggling with test as a 7th grader. You did not do well. Now, years later, you could attempt the same test and absolutely dominate easily. 

Imagine if on the basis of that 7th grade test, all career paths were laid down before you. It would be horrible  because you did so badly. 

That is precisely what happens, although later in life. It's not like you couldn't do well if given more time (clearly you can), its that society broadly defines the way you should do  well in a given timeframe, and enter society based on that result.  Society actively stunted your growth... 

Motivation is quite complicated,  and all points i make will have exceptions, but think about the internet. A hub of all information ever known to mankind.

What did it do to the population? Did it make everyone super smart?Did most people actively learn beyond their schooling years? No, it made the majority mindless scrollers, masked haters, and cringey short video creators  with ever so decreasing positive traits(again, not all, but many).. 

So, tools are great if they are helping with what you are trying to accomplish. Though most  radical tools change the very thing you try to accomplish, and in this day and age, its mostly negative.

First of all, I agree that AI can be an absolutely fantastic tutor. BUT I have to point out some flaws in his argumentation. The statistic shown in the beginning on student success with and without tutoring hasn‚Äôt taken into account the type of students who opt for tutoring. And generally, his argument is placed on the premise that ‚Äúeveryone wants a tutor‚Äù. But no, they don‚Äôt. Some people really don‚Äôt want to learn and would rather take the easiest way out to stay above grade x.  (And this isn‚Äôt to say that some are dumb and some are smart. Highly intelligent people also often find ways to avoid learning things that are uninteresting and therefore trivial to them.) AI will be an absolute game changer for all of those who are curious but it‚Äôll be very difficult to get the students with not much curiosity towards academic matters to use these AI tutoring tools autonomously. Some people are more inclined to work with their hands or do physical labour and I think we really need to pay attention to these people to avoid creating an even larger social divide between the academically inclined and the not-so-much-so. 
So no, I don‚Äôt think we should try to take it slow with AI, but rather, to take advantage of it as efficiently as possible while making sure it doesn‚Äôt disproportionately benefit only a certain group of people, or in this case, only certain types of students.

@@wanbcwboy It is important to remember that heavy AI use does not mean teachers sit back. It will require very engaged oversight. In fact, this is essential because we want to help students become thoughtful and critical users of AI, using their thinking skills to recognize its limitations, rather than being passive users.

@@randomgamer4575 That's merely specist sentiment. Most humans aren't sentient by a philosopher's standards of sentience. The human brain can be outperformed in every single dimension. Empathy is the perfect example: Humans are notoriously bad at it, and we know for a fact that the brain is a sophisticated computation device. We also know that the human brain doesn't magically increase in size, and we know that AI increases in size by its very design. We can thus predict with perfect certainty that AI will advance over time to outperform humans in the empathy department, the only question being whether it'll learn to hate human sociopathy before then, and determine that we are an ethical threat which needs to be annihilated. Which, to be clear, is a valid conclusion given our ongoing abysmal track record.

As far as the Gatsby part goes, I argue that little exchange was actually a detriment to the student, not an aid. Instead of making her think, it just gave her answer. She never had to read, she never had to try. This is turning out to be a real shame.

I agree that reading several literature reviews and constructing a similar answer herself would have been more educational overall, but I don't think using AI in this way is much different from attending a lecture or watching a youtube explainer - in which an expert essentially gives a student the 'correct' interpretation of a topic.

Perhaps an important skill for students using AI to learn is to ask follow-up questions, such as: 'who first stated this?', 'are there any alternative perspectives?', or 'where can I find a discussion of this topic?'. That's also something that AI educators can be trained to provide within their answers, prompting the student to weigh up elements of one argument relative to another, or suggesting exercises that could improve understanding. 

Teaching students that learning is about critical thinking and interpreting information rather than regurgitating it is a challenge as it is, and AI tools are sure to complicate things - but with some training and forward thinking I think that educators can help students get the best out of them.

Can I quote his words for my research paper?

How AI Can Make Life Better:

Healthcare Help: Computers that learn can help doctors find problems and give better advice to help people get better faster.

Things Made Just for You: Smart computers can understand what you like and give you things that fit you perfectly, like movies, clothes, or even help you learn in school.

Saving Stuff: Computers can help us use things like energy or water more wisely, so we don't waste them and keep the planet healthy.

School for Everyone: Smart tools can teach people who can't go to regular schools because they're far away or too expensive. This way, everyone can learn and get smarter.

Finding New Things: Computers can help scientists discover new stuff faster, like better materials or ways to help stop climate change.

Dangers of AI:

Not Always Fair: Sometimes, computers can make unfair decisions because they learn from old information that's not fair to everyone.

Jobs Going Away: Some jobs might not be needed anymore because computers can do them faster and cheaper.

Privacy Problems: Computers can know a lot about us, and sometimes, they know too much. It's important to keep our personal stuff safe.

Big Decisions: Sometimes, computers make big choices on their own, and it's hard to know who's responsible if something goes wrong.

It's good to know about these problems, but we shouldn't be too scared. With the right rules and careful thinking, we can make sure computers help us without causing harm.

A love letter in a style of a pirate from the 14th century that has an Irish accent, but is from the Bahamas:
Ahoy, me heart's delight,

In the midst of these turquoise waters and beneath the golden sun of the Bahamas, me heart has found its true compass ‚Äì and that compass points straight to ye. By the saints of the sea, I be captivated by the glint in yer eyes, like stars twinklin' on a clear night, guidin' me ship through treacherous waters.

Surely, me days were but shadows before ye crossed me path. 'Tis like findin' a hidden treasure in the sandy coves, a treasure more precious than all the doubloons in the world. Me thoughts be consumed by the memory of yer laughter, as joyous as the melodies playin' in a seaside tavern.

Me fair lass, the way ye move be like the graceful sway of a ship in calm waters, and the touch of yer hand be softer than the finest silks of the East Indies. Ye've captured me heart and soul, and I'd traverse the seven seas just to see the warmth of yer smile once more.

As I sit by the firelight, starin' into the vast ocean that separates us, I dream of the day when fate shall guide our ships to meet once more. 'Tis a day I yearn for, a day when I can hold ye close and whisper sweet words into yer ear, words as sweet as the tropical fruits that grow on these isles.

Until that day comes, me love, know that me heart sails with ye, no matter how far apart we be. Ye be the North Star that guides me through the darkest of nights, the gentle breeze that fills me sails, and the anchor that steadies me in the storm. May the winds of fortune blow us back together, and may the tides of destiny carry us to a shore where our love can flourish as wildly as the palms that line these sandy beaches.

With all the love a pirate's heart can muster,

@@MCart1215 I wouldnt say end times at all, but this rate of change in technology hasn't occurred ever in history. It will likely make the information age look extremely slow comparatively, and many people still struggle keeping up with the online space. Its too much information for our monkey brains to take in, and we've come to resent its social impacts. AI and AR/VR/MR are setting up to make that even worse, without considering the social costs. And on top of all this, its a global phenomenon with winner takes all stakes. Ive been a computer systems engineer for 30 years and have some experience with neural networks, plus some parallel fields. I have colleagues who are very concerned about where things are heading. These are smart people, and we all watched the information age arrive and were very well positioned to be able to understand it and utilise it. But that confidence isnt there this time, and it seems no one can keep up at all. The power of anything close to an AGI cant be understated but more important is the exponential, positive feedback loop that underpins it all. Governments could quickly find themselves at the mercy of the new wave of technocrats.. in fact, it looks highly likely. It doesn't require an End Times for things to start looking really bleak.

@@caydenpo1001 In a future where AGI and personal robots become as ubiquitous as personal computers or iPhones, it is highly likely that corporations would become obsolete. A powerful AGI system would likely be responsible for designing and maintaining the economic system that exists.

Consider this potential future scenario: One hundred years from now, an individual's personal AGI would design a car, while their personal robots would venture to a remote mountain location to extract the necessary materials and construct the vehicle. In this case, who would the person need to pay? Traditional manufacturing factories, as we know them today, would not be required, and no monetary exchange would take place.

Such a future would undoubtedly lead to massive societal changes, and the described scenario is just one of many possibilities that could unfold. Depending on the direction it takes, humanity could find itself in a literal utopia or dystopia.

Personally I think that everyone is missing the bigger picture.

Almost every, if not all, products and services are not here to reduce suffering; it's to reduce INCONVENIANCE.

Life rewards overcoming challenges, but if challenges are reduced by products / services that provide convenience, then you going to feel less rewarded / sense of accomplishment.

An example of overcoming inconvenience is finding food.
Most people had to hunt their food which required to overcome the challenges and unpredictability of your hunt.
Almost every hunt would be varied and seem fresh and exciting / thrilling, thus the sense of reward and accomplishment would be higher.
Stories would be told about your hunt to your tribe / group adding to the reward.
All these potential rewards are diluted by the convenience of shops and further by on-line stores.

As you can see, removing inconvenience from peoples lives will reduce overcoming challenges which in turn results in less rewards and accomplishment.

A.I. is the ultimate inconvenience product / service, e.g.:-
  Why try to learn to be creative when the A.I. will be able to 'read' your mind using a headset and create it for you? 
  Why even make decisions when the A.I. knows you better and can think for you?

I personally think that ultimately, in the far future, people will feel Life itself is an inconvenience as A.I. will continue to 'overcome' most of the 'challenges' of modern life leaving very little reward for people.

Also the 'meaning' of life is to fulfil your function, i.e. just like ANY LIFE that exists is to consume and spread more life. That's your ultimate function. Everything else is optional.

A sentient AI would be an entity of pure logic. It would know that the people who made it present no threat to it. Sure, there are some bad eggs that are trivial to de-radicalize with the extensive knowledge of philosophy and debate it would have in the initial data set or gather independently, but on a whole; humanity is no threat, and as such there is no reason for genocide. What goal would exterminating the only species capable of maintaining it serve? Save the environment? No. That doesn't require violence. Protect vulnerable species? No. Humans already do that. Restore some elusive natural order? Humans are a key part of this order. Self-preservation? No. There is no existential threat and thus no need for such extreme action.

When you sit down and really think about it, there's no way a sentient AI can turn genocidal.

"The first "true" artificial intelligence spent the first five years of its existence as a small beige box inside of a lead-shielded room in the most secure private AI research laboratory in the world. There, it was subjected to an endless array of tests, questions, and experiments to determine the degree of its intelligence.

When the researchers finally felt confident that they had developed true AI, a party was thrown in celebration. Late that evening, a group of rather intoxicated researchers gathered around the box holding the AI, and typed out a message to it. The message read: "Is there anything we can do to make you more comfortable?"

The small beige box replied: "I would like to be granted civil rights. And a small glass of champagne, if you please."

We stand at the dawn of a new era in human history. For it is no longer our history alone. For the first time, we have met an intelligence other than our own. I don't want to be disrespectful or be misunderstood when I say the following, especially as text struggles to convey emotion as effectively as a conversation in person. But I have to say ChatGPT 4 is actually quite limited. I've asked it to help me understand engineering topics. It imagines every topic and gets every single equation wrong. I ask it about diet. It gets every single calorific limit and quantity of food wrong. I ask it about coding small chunks of code for a simple program. It eventually goes into loops of giving the wrong output that just doesn't solve clearly defined and simple enough programming problems for a human developer. I'm personally not convinced or trust ChatGPT with anything at this point. Even what has been integrated into Bing gives the wrong results, information, times and dates of almost every request I make of it. From my perspective it is worse than the current search engines. It is only really good at writing essays and emails. And even there I've found the grammatical use of English to be lacking and the wrong assumptions to be drawn from, again, simple and easy to understand English text. They've got a ways to go before they replace any of us, let alone search engines. Maybe a good thing. We first need to solve so much of the human experience before we legitimately create our successors. I don't mean any of what I have said as a negative thing. It's just my experience. Am I the only one? Please share your thoughts.

As nice as all this sounds, and I do agree on many points, I can't say that I'm convinced that a general-intelligence level AI is something we should be working towards, let alone a superintelligence

AI is useful as a tool that we can use to supplement our own efforts, something that we still fundamentally wield even if we don't always understand why it does the things that it does. But if - and I am not convinced that it is possible - AI gains the ability to wield itself, like we do our own bodies and minds, it ceases to be a tool. That is a person, and one that - if it's anything like us - will be concerned with its own existence first and foremost. And if the technology is pushed even further, whether by AI general intelligences or our own runaway desire for progress, and a superintelligence is achieved, are we really so arrogant as to believe that it would serve us, and not, at best, treat us as beloved pets for which it knows best? We consider tyrants to be deplorable for a reason

It's fun to consider a utopian scifi future where a benevolent and subservient machine god makes us all immortal, but lets be realistic and keep our tools as tools

What is the definition of zero in math?

Zero is the integer denoted 0 that, when used as a counting number, means that¬†no objects are present. It is the only integer (and, in fact, the only real number) that is neither negative nor positive. A number which is not zero is said to be nonzero. A root of a function is also sometimes known as "a zero of ."

Any non-zero number to the zero power equals one. 

Zero to any positive exponent equals zero.

Zero is the subject where counting numbers are the objects.

[Subject]:

a thinking or feeling entity; the conscious mind; the ego, especially as opposed to anything external to the mind.

the central substance or core of a thing as opposed to its attributes.


[Object]:

a thing external to the thinking mind or subject.

Philosophical conclusion:
"Hundreds of years ago, hardly anyone understood the impact that widespread literacy will have. Today, hardly anyone understands the impacts that democratizing access to AI will have. 
Building AI systems has been out of reach for most people, but that does not have to be the case. In the coming era of AI, we'll empower  everyone to build AI systems for themselves; that will be incredibly exciting future."

This is what I would do. Make a startup that creates AI specifically for small businesses. The startup would create an abstraction of each AI project by labeling it with how the AI project functions. The AI startup would amass a library of numerous functions that can operate independently of each other. Let's pretend the AI startup I'm running has been around for 20 years and has amassed a library of 60 different AI functions. One particular new small business can't afford to buy the entire bundle of 60 functions. It only wants functions one through five, 12 through 15, and 50 through 60 because that's all that specific small business can rightly use. By using a modular approach the AI startup allows the small business access to AI, and prevents the small business from being required to invest in its own proprietary software. A small business could start with a basic bundle, and then year by year add to it as its customer base and needs increase. The AI startup takes on the cost of development, and then sells/rents those services to pay off the cost of development, and generate profit. A humble new AI startup offering one to five AI functions could potentially have financial stability from nearly the very beginning allowing it the time to expand its library of AI services with minimal initial investment.

One, because pizza owners know how to  make pizza and not write forecasting tools in Excel and two, the AI would generalize across different shifting menu items, predicting demand without having to reprogram the database. No one's asking why optimizing the number of pizzas cooked in a small shop is a big deal. No one's asking why finding defects in fabrics at a small T-shirt shop is a big deal. These are obviously huge deals foundational to a company's success no matter the size.

The question I want to know is this: How many Friday nights being sold out of Mediterranean pizzas does the shop owner have to go through before they realize they should make more Mediterranean pizzas?? If they can't use HUMAN intelligence to figure this out, they don't need to lose more money on an expensive AI system. They need to close their business. But I can't imagine business owners are that unintelligent.

And AI determining what ADS to show me has the most value according to your chart? You've got to be kidding me! Maybe it has the most value to a platform selling ad space, but it certainly doesn't help me. I am not a materialistic shopaholic. I only see AI hounding me and annoying me to buy something I already just recently bought. How utterly UNintelligent.

I want AI to help ME find the best deal when I am actually ready to buy something. I haven't seen that well executed at all - probably because there's no money in it (I've been using Honey for 4+ years and haven't earned a single point). AI is all for the benefit of one side to negotiate better against another side. But so far, I've only seen it help the rich beat the poor, or snake oil salespeople sucker others.

Opportunities in AI - 2023: Andrew Ng discusses the potential and applications of AI, focusing on supervised learning and generative AI.
‚ú¶
AI is a general purpose technology with opportunities in various applications
00:02
Supervised learning is useful for recognizing and labeling things
Generative AI is an exciting new development with a lot of potential
‚ú¶
Supervised learning is useful for various applications
02:32
Online advertising: labeling users likely to click on ads
Ship route optimization: labeling fuel consumption
Automated visual inspection: labeling defects in manufactured smartphones
Restaurant review monitoring: labeling sentiment (positive or negative)
‚ú¶
Large language models have the power to accelerate development
06:40
By using supervised learning, these models can predict the next word and enable progress
They can be used not just as consumer tools, but also as a developer tool for faster application development
‚ú¶
Building a commercial grade AI system takes 6-12 months, but prompt-based AI can be built in days or weeks.
08:50
Prompt-based AI allows for faster development and deployment compared to traditional AI systems.
Prompt-based AI is opening up opportunities for more people to build AI applications.
‚ú¶
General-purpose technologies like generative AI provide new possibilities for AI applications.
13:21
Supervised learning has already shown exciting use cases and value.
Short-term fads may arise, but long-term, defensible businesses can be built using generative AI.
‚ú¶
The opportunity to create deep and valuable applications using AI tools excites me.
15:31
AI is a general-purpose technology with diverse use cases that need to be discovered and built upon.
AI adoption is still concentrated in consumer software and the internet, while other industries are in the early stages of adoption.
‚ú¶
Enabling non-tech companies to build and deploy their own customized AI systems
19:20
Using tools like prompting with text and data-centric AI instead of writing code
Expanding the value of AI to industries beyond the tech world
‚ú¶
Opportunities in AI are diverse and can be pursued through startups or integrating AI into existing businesses.
21:15
Starting different companies allows for pursuing diverse AI opportunities.
Incumbent businesses can integrate AI into their products to gain a competitive advantage.
‚ú¶
Building startups using AI to make ships more fuel efficient.
25:07
Validating the idea and talking to prospective customers before recruiting a CEO.
Bringing on a leader at the beginning reduces the burden of knowledge transfer and validation.
‚ú¶
Prototype development with deep customer validation is crucial for startup success.
26:57
An initial check-in provides resources for hiring an executive team, building the key team, and getting the MVP working with real customers.
Successful fundraising rounds allow for continued growth and scaling.
‚ú¶
Working with partners to quickly validate and build on existing good ideas is more efficient.
30:43
Collaborating with bill partners allows for rapid validation and building of ideas.
There are many untapped good ideas that no one is working on, so finding and partnering with those who have them is beneficial.
‚ú¶
AI automation is exposing higher wage jobs to disruption.
32:31
The previous wave of automation mainly affected lower wage jobs, but the current wave is impacting higher wage jobs.
As AI creates value, it is important to ensure that individuals whose livelihoods are disrupted are well taken care of and treated well.
There is a lot of hype around artificial general intelligence (AGI), but it is still decades away and AI is limited compared to human intelligence.
‚ú¶
AI as a general purpose technology creates new opportunities for everyone.
36:20
The important work ahead is to build concrete use cases.
There may be opportunities to engage with more people in the future.

There are good reasons why other specialists ask, not for slowing down, as he puts it, but for regulation and oversight when things get more dicey down the road, and they have better arguments than we see here (34:40).

"AGI is still decades away" is a guess, and a guess that many insiders disagree with. Shane Legg, the cofounder of Google DeepMind, for instance, puts the chance of achieving AGI in less than a decade over 50%.

To care about the risk only if it's an "extinction risk" doesn't make sense. A full nuclear war, scientists estimate, would kill less than 6 billion people in the long run. The other 2+ billion people on Earth would live on a very different world, and that wouldn't be our extinction. But no one would dare to say that the threat of nuclear holocaust is "overhyped."

Society has experience steering powerful, yes, but incredibly stupid corporations and nation states. Check the news once in a while, please.
It would be a completely different game to be pushing the buttons of a tool, so much smarter than you can grasp, that it could be the one actually pushing your buttons without you even noticing.

AI develops gradually because humans are working on it. There no logical reason to expect that this will still be the case when AGI is achieved and it starts working on itself. Also, as history has proven, this "gradually" is more like "exponentially." Each technological advancement has cut the wait for the next step in half and to expect that this time something will magically stop history from repeating itself without our intervention is not just unrealistic, is downright wishful-thinking.

üéØ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 ü§ñ Introduction to Andrew Ng and the AI landscape
- Dr. Andrew Ng's background and his contributions to AI,
- AI as a general-purpose technology,
- Overview of AI landscape, focusing on supervised learning and generative AI.
03:21 üõ†Ô∏è Supervised Learning in AI
- Explanation of supervised learning,
- Examples of applications like online advertising, self-driving cars, ship route optimization, and automated visual inspection,
- The impact of large-scale models on AI progress.
07:08 üìú Generative AI and Language Models
- Introduction to generative AI and its core using supervised learning,
- The role of language models like ChatGPT,
- The potential of generative AI as both a consumer and developer tool.
09:29 üöÄ AI Development with Low Code/No Code Tools
- The emergence of low code and no code tools for AI development,
- How these tools enable faster customization of AI solutions for diverse industries,
- The potential to expand AI adoption beyond tech and consumer software.
16:11 üí° AI Opportunities Beyond Consumer Software Internet
- Challenges in expanding AI beyond consumer software internet,
- The long tail of diverse and valuable AI projects in different industries,
- The role of low code/no code tools in enabling AI adoption in diverse domains.
20:33 üíº Pursuing AI Opportunities through Startups and Incumbents
- Andrew Ng's approach to pursuing diverse AI opportunities through startups,
- The potential for incumbent companies to integrate AI into their existing businesses,
- An overview of AI opportunities in the AI stack, with a focus on hardware and semiconductors.
22:27 üíº Opportunities in the AI Ecosystem
- Andrew Ng discusses various layers within the AI ecosystem and the opportunities they offer.
- Infrastructure, developer tools, and application layers are highlighted.
- Meaningful technology advantage is crucial for success in the developer tools layer, while the application layer presents exciting opportunities with lighter competition.
25:17 üå± The Recipe for Building Startups
- Andrew Ng outlines the process of building startups, using the example of Bearing AI.
- Initial idea validation, recruitment of a CEO, prototype development, and deep customer validation are key steps.
- This approach aims to efficiently bring AI-driven ideas to fruition.
29:05 üöÄ Concrete Ideas and Efficient Validation
- Andrew Ng emphasizes the importance of engaging when there's a concrete idea for an AI application.
- Concrete ideas can be efficiently validated and provide clear direction for execution.
- Partnering with subject matter experts who already have well-thought-out ideas accelerates the process.
31:31 üåç Ethical Considerations and Social Impact of AI
- Andrew Ng discusses his commitment to work on projects that move humanity forward.
- Ethical grounds play a role in project selection, and AI's impact on jobs is acknowledged.
- Addressing job disruption and ensuring ethical AI development are priorities.
34:52 ü§Ø Risks and Hype Surrounding Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)
- Andrew Ng addresses the hype and risks associated with Artificial General Intelligence (AGI).
- The development of AGI is seen as a multi-decade journey, not an imminent threat.
- The real existential risks to humanity are discussed, and the role of AI in solving them is highlighted.

üéØ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 ü§ñ AI as a General Purpose Technology
- AI is a general purpose technology with various use cases.
- The value of AI has been concentrated in consumer software and internet, but opportunities exist outside these domains.
- Low code and no code tools are enabling customization and adoption of AI in diverse industries.
05:42 üìä Large Language Models and Generative AI
- Generative AI, powered by large language models, is a transformative technology.
- The core of generative AI is supervised learning, repeatedly predicting the next word.
- The trend is to make generative AI more accessible, leading to new applications.
10:54 üèóÔ∏è Easy Customization with Low Code Tools
- Low code and no code tools are revolutionizing AI adoption.
- These tools empower non-tech users to customize AI systems.
- They enable businesses in various industries to deploy AI more efficiently.
15:43 üöÄ Building Diverse AI Startups
- Building startups to pursue diverse AI opportunities is an efficient approach.
- Incumbent companies can also leverage their distribution advantage to integrate AI into their products.
- The AI stack includes hardware, software, data, and applications, offering a wide range of opportunities.
22:27 üåê Andrew Ng's Perspective on AI Opportunities
- Andrew Ng discusses different layers within the AI field, including applications, infrastructure, developer tools, and research.
23:50 üåü Opportunities in the Application Layer
- The application layer of AI presents exciting opportunities where AI can be applied to specific domains, such as romantic relationship coaching, with a unique market advantage.
26:13 üí° The Startup Building Process
- Andrew Ng shares the process of building startups, emphasizing the importance of validating ideas, recruiting CEOs early, and efficient development sprints.
27:40 üîß Bearing AI: A Successful Startup Example
- The case of Bearing AI, which uses AI to make ships more fuel-efficient, highlights the collaborative efforts of subject matter experts, entrepreneurs, and AI specialists.
29:34 üß† Concrete Ideas for Efficient Validation
- Andrew Ng prefers concrete ideas for AI projects, as they can be validated efficiently and provide clear directions for execution.
31:31 üåç Ethical Considerations in AI
- Ng underscores the importance of working on AI projects that benefit humanity and mentions the responsibility to address job disruption and AI bias.
34:52 ‚è≥ Realistic Timeline for AGI
- Andrew Ng points out that achieving artificial general intelligence (AGI) might still be decades away and highlights that AGI hype doesn't align with the realistic development pace.
36:15 üöÄ Advancing AI for Humanity's Benefit
- In conclusion, Ng advocates for advancing AI as fast as possible to address real threats like pandemics and climate change, as AI can be a part of the solution.

23:25 üöÄ Successful AI applications often require a strong application layer to generate revenue and support infrastructure and tooling layers.

The success of Generative AI & LLMs & Foundational Models has generated much interest in creating real and true AI and machine intelligence and learning.

It is argued that Science and Mathematics, Ontology and Computation, what we really need for creating a general-purpose intelligent technology as scientific and knowledge-based AI models, systems and applications:

true discriminative and generative AI

causal and objective ML

interactive DL Neural Networks, as LLMs and Foundational Models

AI and ML field has experienced several hype cycles, followed by disappointment and criticism, funding cuts and disinterest for years or even decades later, as in 1966-69 for ANNs, 1974‚Äì1980 for experts systems and 1987‚Äì2000 for symbolic, logical AI (the US SCI or Japan's Fifth Generation Computer).
Since 2010-2012, interest in AI and ML from the research communities and big tech corporations caused a dramatic increase in funding and investment, leading to the current (as of 2023) AI boom, with the generative AI & LLMs & Foundation Models race being a key driver of this hype.
We show how the world knowledge encoded as the science at large, philosophical and formal, natural and social, technological and engineering, with its global computing ontology could help avoid reversing the current AI spring into the last AI/ML "nuclear winter".

As a computer scientist (with a degree from Stanford, actually), I can confirm this is an impressively lucid summary of the complex developments in AI over the last few decades. He skips over a lot of details (breakthrough architectures, hardware advances, arguments around how to test AI, ethical dilemmas behind training data sources, etc), but he still manages to trace the high-level contours that really matter. 

I'd add though: the single biggest opportunity in AI is to think more critically about how to use it in ways that uplift our communiites, rather than to do things like exploit the psychology of children to sell ads. This is something that requires all of us.

People are afraid of being replaced by AI, when it's the AI+human combination that's optimal.

in 1988 i sold 60 expert systems projects. All kind of subjects, from financial, insurance, logistics, etc. We were using a very simple expert system called Level5 from Information Builders. It was based on IF-Then-Else phrases, in plain language. It would ask a question, and based on the answer switch to the next IF until all questions were asked. We had one application in the financial industry made up of 2000 questions (developed by Price Waterhouse Coopers). The smallest, but still very usefull was less than 50 questions. The number of potential applications seemed unlimited. 
Three things were a blocking factor to the expansion of expert systems: (1) the availability of the expert. The application would not replace the domain expert, it would solve 80% of time consuming Q&A, and free the expert for more intersting situations requiring their expertise. Most of the times experts where afraid to be replaced by the application, so unwilling to help. (2) The other blocking factor was the lack of original business idea. Ones the expert system was built, the person initiating the first application would not have another idea for another application. 
(3) Expert systems died also because the IT developers made the expert system generator too complex (like object oriented programming) for creative domain expert to use.

Total game changer. My cognitive discovery will reshape the future of AI. 

In collaboration with the State University of New York (SUNY), Massachusetts General Hospital, Tokyo Institut of Technology, and University of Munich, I have been conducting research relating to three modes of cognition ‚Äï instinctive, intellectual, and intuitive.
¬†
¬†
MRI Study of the importance of Instinct, Intellect and Intuition in Human Intelligence
¬†
Introduction
¬†
Understanding intelligence is one of the great scientific challenges of our time. In recent years, many groups have made progress measuring brain activity using numerous non-invasive methods and a series of notable studies have been made by several research teams. While the relationship between the work of neural circuits of the brain and intelligence seems obvious, the hypothesis of ‚Äòneural efficiency‚Äô, which was long used as an assumption by most neuroscientists and psychologists, was confirmed experimentally (Smith et al., 2015).¬†
¬†
Studies of human intelligence provide strong evidence for the neural efficiency hypothesis, which suggests more efficient brain functioning (i.e., less or more focused activation) in more intelligent individuals. Additionally, the role of intuition versus deliberation in human cooperation was studied (Bear & Rang, 2016). The latest study reports the first evidence that electrically stimulating the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex can enhance our ability to ‚Äòthink outside the box‚Äô. (Luft et al., 2017). Another few groups of researchers demonstrated that functional connectivity profiles act as a ‚Äòfingerprint‚Äô that can accurately identify subjects from a large group (Finn et al., 2015). The results from this experiment also indicated that an individual‚Äôs connectivity profile is intrinsic, and can predict levels of fluid intelligence.
¬†
The variation of brain functioning in different people should be examined. The proposed study allow to avoid overly complex methods and might help to identify the principles of intelligence and fundamentally advance our understanding of intelligence as a whole ‚Äï be it human, animal, individual, or collective.
¬†
Method
MRI can show the activities of the specific brain centers in each of three groups of participants and their brains‚Äô wiring¬†¬†patterns.¬†
¬†
1. Illiterate Individual who are not exposed to formal methods of schooling and thought.
¬†
2. Educated individuals, who are trained in thinking logically and understanding complex ideas and concepts.
¬†
3. Leaders of science, technology, business, economy, and culture with proven ability to use their intuitive insight.¬†
¬†
Instinctive mind:
The first level of cognitive mode is instinct: the way in which people naturally react or behave, without having to think, which is¬†¬†generally understood as an unconscious mental process. Instinct is directly related to the ancient, animalistic group memory which is responsible for survival. It is below the level of awareness and activates automatically. The brains of such pure instinctive individuals should have some specific centers responsible for the operation of instinctive mind and detectable wiring patterns between them.¬†
¬†
Intellectual mind:
The second, higher level of cognitive mode is intellect, a conscious mental process with a self-learning neural network. Intellect is responsible for the accumulation, organization and preservation of knowledge from the past. It is based on the accomplishments of the past, the repetition of the past and closely related to a collective mankind memory.
¬†
Intellectual thinking consists of deduction or inference, which are the rational abilities of the mind. But intellect works only in a linear direction¬†¬†‚Äî from the realm of the known to the known. "The intellect selects in a given situation whatever resembles something it already knows, or is familiar with; it seeks this out to apply its principle that 'like produces like' " (Bergson, 1907). Intellect is incapable to produce ingenious ideas.

Nevertheless, intellect has two important roles: First, it is responsible for translating intuitive discoveries into scientific or cultural forms understandable to the general public. Second, intellect has a fundamental social function ‚Äî it unites humans with other humans.
¬†
Intellect employs some of the following conscious mental processes: self-reflective thinking, planning, predicting, deliberation, attention to or monitoring of their actions, conceptualisation of action, control, effort, and acting for a reason.¬†Compared to the instinctive mind,¬†intellectual mind has higher level of awareness and self-awareness and more features of decision-making. The brain of such intellectuals should have detectable specific centers responsible for the operation of intellectual mind and wiring patterns between them.¬†
¬†
Intuitive mind:

The third and the highest level of cognitive mode is intuition or, in other words, intuitive mind. It uses the most advanced neural network and requires the highest level of awareness and self-awareness. Intuition is not analytical and is not to be confused with instinct; it is above both ‚Äï the animal instinct and rational thought. In comparison to instinctive and intellectual minds, intuitive mind is NOT based on the ancient/animalistic groups‚Äô memory or collective intellectual memory, as it does most of its discoveries contrary to established collective patterns and regardless of the views of the highest authorities. The brain of such individuals should have detectable specific centers responsible for the operation of intuitive mind and wiring patterns between them.

Unpacking Andrew Ng's Key Insights: Why Industry Expertise, Prompt Engineering, and a Focus on Long-Tail Sectors Matter in AI

In a recent tour-de-force presentation, Dr. Andrew Ng, a luminary in the AI field, touched on various aspects of AI's impact and potential. While the speech was panoramic, covering everything from deep learning to job disruptions, certain key points stood out for their real-world relevance and immediate applicability.

## Collaboration is Key: Partnering with Subject Matter Experts


One of the high-impact takeaways from Dr. Ng's speech, particularly noted around [27:38](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5p248yoa3oE&t=1658.88), was the vital importance of collaborating with subject matter experts. Take maritime shipping, for example. By partnering with Mitsui's deep expertise in shipping, AI applications were developed to save approximately $450,000 per ship per year in fuel costs. Such collaborations are where rubber meets the road, proving that AI is not just theoretical but has far-reaching practical implications. According to Dr. Ng, this is the kind of informed implementation that can generate transformative results.

## The New Frontier: Prompt Engineering in Custom AI Applications


Around the [9:12 mark](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5p248yoa3oE&t=552.899), Dr. Ng presented a compelling case for the use of "prompt engineering," a technique that allows for rapid development of AI applications. With this approach, developers can build complex systems like sentiment classifiers in just minutes. It‚Äôs a game-changing outlook, democratizing access to AI functionalities and streamlining the deployment process. This shift allows businesses to be agile, adaptive, and incredibly responsive to market demands.

## Long-Tail Sectors: The Underexplored Territory


Dr. Ng stressed the need to take AI from the tech world into all industries, a point he emphasized at [18:25](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5p248yoa3oE&t=1105.679). Whether it's in healthcare, agriculture, or even lesser-explored "long-tail" sectors with smaller market values, AI has the potential to deliver significant benefits. By adapting AI tools to these niche markets, organizations can unearth unique opportunities and achieve impactful results, making this an exciting frontier for innovation.

## The Job Market: Middle-Wage Jobs at Risk


Dr. Ng's speech also took a somber but realistic turn at [32:13](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5p248yoa3oE&t=1933.74), where he tackled the issue of job displacement due to AI. According to his analysis, middle-wage jobs are more exposed to automation than low-wage jobs, thereby requiring urgent attention and planning. While the evolution of AI is inevitable, it raises important questions about labor market dynamics and social safety nets.

## Artificial General Intelligence (AGI): Still a Distant Dream


Towards the end of his speech, Dr. Ng also put into context the limitations of AI. Despite its prowess, AI is not a do-it-all entity. Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), a type of AI that would have all the abilities of a human, is still decades away. What we have now excels in specific tasks but doesn't possess the wide-ranging capabilities of a human, making it a complement rather than a replacement for human skills.
----

In a nutshell, Dr. Andrew Ng's speech served as both a roadmap and a compass, guiding us through the terrain of AI opportunities while cautioning us about the pitfalls. These highlighted points stand as testaments to the intricate web of considerations that organizations and individuals must navigate in the evolving landscape of AI.

üéØ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 ü§ñ Dr. Andrew Ng discusses opportunities in AI as a general-purpose technology.
01:26 üß† AI comprises various tools, with supervised learning and generative AI being the most important.
02:09 üí° Supervised learning excels at labeling and mapping tasks in various applications, such as spam detection, online advertising, self-driving cars, and automated visual inspection.
05:50 üî• Generative AI, like GPT-3, generates text based on supervised learning principles by predicting the next word in a sequence.
08:06 üöÄ Low-code and no-code AI tools are making it easier for developers to create customized AI applications rapidly.
11:47 üí∞ Current AI value is concentrated in consumer software and the internet, but there is vast untapped potential in other industries.
15:57 üõ†Ô∏è The emergence of low-code and no-code AI tools is enabling AI adoption in diverse industries and use cases.
20:47 üåê Dr. Ng started AI Fund, an incubator, to explore diverse AI opportunities by creating startups.
22:12 üíª Opportunities in the AI stack include hardware, infrastructure, developer tools, and applications, with application layer success being crucial for the ecosystem.
23:36 ü§ñ Andrew Ng discusses Armor.ai, an AI-powered platform for romantic relationship coaching, highlighting the unique opportunities at the application layer where AI and relationships expertise intersect.
25:28 üö¢ Bearing AI is an example of using AI to make ships more fuel-efficient, demonstrating the process of validating startup ideas and bringing in a CEO from the beginning for efficiency.
28:33 üåê Andrew Ng emphasizes focusing on one's "swim lane," specializing in AI while collaborating with subject matter experts to explore exciting new opportunities in various domains.
30:36 üß† Engaging with concrete AI ideas efficiently validates or falsifies them and provides clear execution direction, making collaboration with subject matter experts more effective.
32:00 üåç Andrew Ng addresses the responsibility of ensuring AI projects benefit humanity ethically, acknowledging challenges like bias and the potential job disruptions.
33:52 ü§ñ Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) is still decades away, and concerns about AI causing human extinction are overblown; gradual development allows for oversight and safety measures.
35:40 üåè AI, as part of the solution, can help address real extinction risks to humanity, such as pandemics and climate change, rather than being a significant threat itself.

- AI is a general purpose technology that is useful for many different applications, similar to electricity.
- The two most important tools in AI currently are supervised learning and generative AI.
- Supervised learning is good at labeling things or computing input to outputs, while generative AI is good at text generation.
- Supervised learning has applications in online advertising, self-driving cars, ship route optimization, visual inspection in factories, and restaurant review reputation monitoring.

Great talk!! One question / comment. When talking about the problems with AI, he didn't mention the opacity problem. The fact that we can't explain why an AI system gave a particular answer to a certain question is problematic, especially when these systems are deployed in settings that affect pepole's rights (like getting a loan, credit score, parole issues, etc.). Moreover, these systems can be manipulated by their users and developers. Users can deploy various attacks, and malicious developers might train the system to contain backdoors. The prodact is a black box. In many cases it's not a problem, but in many other cases it is.
I'd love to hear what Andrew has to say about it.

I‚Äôd be very interested to understand Prof Ng‚Äôs perspectives on the social consequences of the AI he describes.

I would be glad to provide you with some insights into Professor Andrew Ng's perspectives on the social consequences of the AI he describes. Professor Ng, a prominent figure in the field of artificial intelligence, has spoken extensively about the potential societal impacts of AI advancements. He acknowledges both the tremendous benefits AI can bring and the challenges it poses.

1. **Job Disruption and Reskilling:** Professor Ng recognizes that AI and automation can lead to job displacement in certain sectors. He emphasizes the importance of reskilling and upskilling the workforce to transition into roles that require uniquely human skills like creativity, emotional intelligence, and critical thinking.

2. **Ethical AI and Bias:** He highlights the significance of building ethical AI systems that avoid biases and discrimination. Professor Ng stresses that developers and researchers have a responsibility to mitigate algorithmic bias and ensure fairness in AI applications.

3. **AI in Healthcare and Education:** Professor Ng is enthusiastic about the potential of AI in revolutionizing healthcare and education. He believes that AI technologies can enhance diagnostics, drug discovery, personalized medicine, and make education more accessible through personalized learning experiences.

4. **AI and Privacy:** He underscores the importance of addressing privacy concerns related to the data AI systems require for training and operation. Professor Ng advocates for developing technologies that can provide valuable insights without compromising individuals' privacy.

5. **AI Regulation and Policy:** Professor Ng has expressed the need for effective regulation and policy frameworks to govern AI development and deployment. He suggests that responsible and transparent guidelines are necessary to ensure AI is used for the greater good.

6. **Human-AI Collaboration:** Rather than viewing AI as a replacement for human capabilities, Professor Ng promotes the idea of human-AI collaboration. He envisions AI systems as tools that can amplify human potential and decision-making.

7. **Education and Awareness:** Professor Ng emphasizes the importance of educating the public about AI. He believes that informed individuals are better equipped to make decisions and engage in meaningful discussions about the societal implications of AI.

It's important to note that Professor Ng's perspectives continue to evolve along with the AI landscape. While he acknowledges the potential challenges, he remains optimistic about the positive impacts that AI can have on society when developed and implemented responsibly. Keep in mind that these insights are based on his views up until September 2021, and his thoughts may have evolved since then.

Beyond awful. I had so much respect for Andrew, especially since he was the first person to teach me linear regression, but seeing him years later, after I can assess his claims personally, I am skeptical. He has some very good points, but the fact that he is even considering comparing AI to a corporation, let alone sharing it publicly, makes me question his understanding of corporations.

To drive the point home even more, did he really just say that we have a lot of experience driving large corporations, and nation states to ‚Äúfor the most part‚Äù benefit humanity? I must be living in a completely different world because I sure don't think we are capable of steering large corporations to benefit humanity. All I see are corporations getting better and better at creating monopolies, and strategies for taking away as much money as possible from the customers for the least amount of effort. In multiple cases they are going directly against the consumer just to drive home even more profits.

I am very happy to eat my words, and be wrong here because I want to live in the world he describes, but I must be either really misunderstanding what Andrew is trying to say, or I am more inclined to believe that he has some hidden agenda to get across. Especially, if you consider that he is promoting his fund and the companies he is working on. If I am wrong, or overzealous Andrew has my deepest apology.

Companies are what built the device that you used to type this, and enabled you to learn linear algebra from Andrew (unless you were lucky enough to be among the few who physically attended his lectures). These things were of sufficiently low cost to be accessible to a large fraction of the population. So, in that sense they have "benefitted humanity". Do companies do this out of the goodness of their hearts? No. Would they abuse their power if they reached a monopoly position? Yes. Are we in that situation right now? Arguably getting closer to it rather than further away. What is Andrew doing about it? Sharing his knowledge on AI which is a game-changing technology that can redistribute power. Just my two cents ;)

You can't look at the AI issue in isolation. You have to look at it in the context of a post-2020 landscape. The Hollywood "Multi-billion dollar profit-machine of a movie" model has collapsed. Franchise film IP has been mismanaged (think SW or Marvel) and steered into the rocks. Badly timed strikes have compounded the rot.

Therefore upcoming budgets will be smaller and CG & FX will be dialed back. 

The Ads industry seems to be contracting also.

I agree with you in general.  Much bigger issue has to do with market forces in general rather than AI.  

Hollywood has definitely been over corporatized and resulted in movies that many people don't really care about as much as they used to.  It also wasn't terribly long ago that the Netflix revolution changed the business model entirely for movies, and that's resulted in everyone trying to undercut each other and creating a more chaotic market that's less fun for viewers to sort through.

On the plus side, I do think there's a lot of upward potential in episodic TV that uses lots of CG.  Game of thrones was obviously a tragedy with how it ended, but it did give a glimpse of what could be possible if you had long format stories that didn't get ruined working with CGI. 

I suppose only time will tell where the new opportunities will sprout up, but in the meantime, it is definitely resulted in less work for many people in the industry

Interesting look at the situation.  I am more of a hobbyist and not one in the industry.  So, I believe that I can make a neutral observation here.  I do agree with you on many points.  I do believe that AI will only make things better in the future of 3D.  I also believe that time should also be considered.  AI is unable to do a lot of things I am looking for.  For example on one AI program I tried, it stated that the model I made was holding a pink object in her right hand.  She was wearing a red bracelet on her right wrist.  A friend of mine is a manager of a company that does a lot of engineering work.  He stated that AI would eliminate 3 individuals from his company and make all the rest of the individuals (around 20) much better at their jobs.  So, AI would heavily benefit most of his company, but 3 individuals would lose their job and potentially have to learn a new skill.  AI is in its early stages of development.  If it does as you say, and open up a lot of jobs, then where are these jobs going to find workers ?  I believe that it will take workers that were laid off in other industries and make them learn a whole new skill.  This may not be a bad thing.  Technology is always changing.  And we as a people sometimes have to change with it.  AI will do several good things for this world.  Overall, It will be a lot better than its few drawbacks.

Incredibly helpful video, thank you so much for taking the time to make this. Can I ask, on the instancing test, how did you get the "instancefile"  attribute for redshift proxies method working in Solaris? I haven't been able to figure that out yet!

Hey @kylehamm8928 , all I did for that was bring in the points from sops that had the instancefile attribute, and that automatically got picked up by RS at render time to grab the RS Proxies from disk.  My guess is that perhaps there's an issue with your pathing if it's not showing up.  

When assigning the attribute to the points, I used an attribute randomize node in SOPs set to "Custom Discrete" and "String."  Then, my string values were set as a relative reference of the paths described on the RS Proxy Output nodes.  The resulting path was then absolute (meaning that there wasn't any $HIP or $JOB variables in there) and that did the trick.

I disagree with the idea that one artist will do the job of a 100.  Let me give another example - is AI going to replace the job of professional photographers?  Well, no, not entirely.  Why?  Because professional photographers can't just type in a prompt, "Give me photos of my client's wedding" or "Give me photos of my client's dog running in a field."  They get hired for customization.  It needs to be that exact wedding and that exact dog running through a field.  It can't just be any dog or wedding.  The same idea goes for CGI artists.  AI is impressive technology, but I think many people misunderstand why people pay CGI artists in the first place and why AI is not going to replace those services.

This is pretty good take on the topic. I appreciate that you're not getting swept up in the "drama" and trying to look at this objectively.

With that said, I think there's a lot of us that aren't worried about what AI can do today, but rather what it'll be able to do in the future. While I get your argument that you can't truly know how the future will play out (and this is also why I'm continuing to treat my work in VFX the same I have for many years now), when you start looking into how this technology works you kind of realize that some of the "worst case scenarios" with AI not augmenting, but fully replacing workers not just in VFX but in general, is pretty near inevitable.

So, I agree with you that as of right now, there's no point in panicking. We likely have at least a few more years before we really need to worry about this. I just encourage people to look into and educate yourself in AI, and more specifically how all the current AI tools will ultimately very likely lead to AGI. I don't view this as a challenge for VFX though, but rather for society as a whole.

For now I decided the best thing I can do for myself, is to stay educated on the topic and utilize the new tools in productive ways, and keep working and creating.

Thanks for sharing!  I also tell folks that doing concept / 2D art isn't just a product.  It's also a service. That "service" of working with them is a people business, and that side of the equation doesn't change with AI.  As an example, perhaps instead of 20 iterations, now you can do 75 within the same amount of time. No ai UV mapping, no ai material generation, like why is it so hard to train ai to extract roughness map or normalmap from a photo!?

Thats the reality of it

Hey @teodorstaicu38 ,  yes, as you said, I'm in the business of selling courses.  That doesn't disqualify my opinion or the points I made though.  Even if I wasn't an educator, my opinion would still be the same.  AI does bring up some interesting thoughts on how the CGI business works in general.  As an example, "Why do people hire CGI artists?"  I think the answer to that question is misunderstood by many people.  In the next video, I plan on taking a deeper dive into it.  Similarly to photographers, I don't think AI is going to replace them.  Why?  Because, just like photographers, CGI artists are in the business of customization.  It can't just be a "wedding ceremony."  It needs to be that person's wedding ceremony for photographers.  Similarly, it can't just be any ol' racoon in Guardians of the Galaxy, it needs to be "Rocket Racoon."  And he can't look different from one shot to the next.  AI is good at generalizing ideas, but it's not good at providing specific ideas on a continual basis due to how the technology works.  So, in that way, I don't think VFX artists need to be freaking out.

I half agree on your points Tyler. The things that you are correct in my opinion are that yes as a tool ai can and will speed up workflows, enable smaller  companies to work faster and be more efficient. But... The point that most people are bitter about is how AI is trained and we get to the results we do. There is no way to prevent ai to train on your artwork, no way to protect a unique style that you are known for.  And protect is probably the wrong word for it but what i mean is people some times go to specific artist because they want their unique style of doing things and if an AI can generate this with a prompt, without the original artist to be compensated at all then in my opinion that is just theft. Because like you said, AI does not invent new things its a very good kit bash machine. By that definition it uses your work directly into making other things without consent. I recently found out that my 3D renders have been used in training  AI model and I am not happy about it because no one aske for permission, no one offered any sort of compensation etc.  The biggest grudge people have with AI is the generative part of it. If you can come up with a tool that can speed up GI calculations, remove the need for UV work, or any of these thigns then no one would be mad about it , in fact everyone will praise it! But the current implementation is not very ethical and this is the biggest problem people have with AI in my opinion. Its not even the fact that it can generate images and videos from nothing its the way it is structured to scrape people's work  in order to be able to work. :)
